questions.question_text_1: A chair manufacturer hires its assembly-line labour for $30 an hour and calculates that the rental cost of its machinery is $15 per hour. questions.question_text_1: Elmo finds himself at a Coke machine on a hot and dusty Sunday. The Coke machine requires exact change-two quarters and a dime. No other combination of coins will make anything come out of the machine. No stores are open; no one is in sight. Elmo is so thirsty that the only thing he cares about is how many soft drinks he will be able to buy with the change in his pocket; the more he can buy, the better.   Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Elmo finds himself at a Coke machine on a hot and dusty Sunday. The Coke machine requires exact change-two quarters and a dime. No other combination of coins will make anything come out of the machine. No stores are open; no one is in sight. Elmo is so thirsty that the only thing he cares about is how many soft drinks he will be able to buy with the change in his pocket; the more he can buy, the better.   Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: If Elmo has 2 quarters and a dime in his pockets, he can buy 1 soft drink. How many soft drinks can he buy if he has 4 quarters and 2 dimes?____________

questions.question_text_1: Last week you purchased five large cases of Fritos for a customer who, as it turned out, did not accept delivery. You paid $100 for these cases. You have a deal with your grocers that they will pay you $0.25 for each dollar of returned merchandise. Just this week, you found a fraternity on campus that will buy the five cartons for $55 (and will pick them up from your apartment, relieving you of the need to deliver them to the frat house).  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Last week you purchased five large cases of Fritos for a customer who, as it turned out, did not accept delivery. You paid $100 for these cases. You have a deal with your grocers that they will pay you $0.25 for each dollar of returned merchandise. Just this week, you found a fraternity on campus that will buy the five cartons for $55 (and will pick them up from your apartment, relieving you of the need to deliver them to the frat house).  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. Production Functions
- **Cobb-Douglas Production Function**: \( F(K, L) = K^p L^q \)
  - **Returns to Scale**:
    - Increasing returns to scale: \( p + q > 1 \)
    - Decreasing returns to scale: \( p + q < 1 \)
    - Constant returns to scale: \( p + q = 1 \)

#### 2. Preferences and Utility
- **Completeness**: Ability to compare and choose between two goods.
- **Reflexivity**: A good is at least as good as itself.
- **Transitivity**: If a person prefers A to B and B to C, then they should prefer A to C.
- **Convexity**: Preference for diversity or balanced combinations of goods.

#### 3. Marginal Product of Labor
- **Definition**: The extra output produced by employing one more unit of labor while holding other inputs constant.
- **Equation**: \( MP_L = \frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta L} \)

#### 4. Cost Minimization
- **Marginal Cost (MC)**: The cost of producing one more unit of a good.
- **Average Total Cost (ATC)**: Total cost divided by the number of units produced.
- **Optimal Combination of Inputs**: Minimizing cost given the prices of inputs.
  - **Equation**: \( \frac{MP_L}{P_L} = \frac{MP_K}{P_K} \)

#### 5. Production Function and Cost Optimization
- **Production Function**: \( q = 100KL \)
- **Optimal Capital-Labor Ratio**: \( \frac{K}{L} = \frac{MP_L}{MP_K} \times \frac{P_K}{P_L} \)
- **Cost Function**: \( TC = 100 + 25q + q^2 \)
  - **Average Fixed Cost (AFC)**: \( \frac{FC}{q} \)
  - **Marginal Cost (MC)**: \( \frac{d(TC)}{dq} \)
  - **Average Variable Cost (AVC)**: \( \frac{VC}{q} \)

#### 6. Opportunity Cost
- **Definition**: The cost of the next best alternative that must be forgone in order to pursue a certain action.
- **Equation**: Opportunity Cost = Return of best foregone option - Return of chosen option

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Managerial Economics] --> B[Production Functions]
    A --> C[Preferences and Utility]
    A --> D[Marginal Product of Labor]
    A --> E[Cost Minimization]
    A --> F[Production Function and Cost Optimization]
    A --> G[Opportunity Cost]

    B --> B1[Cobb-Douglas Production Function]
    B --> B2[Returns to Scale]

    C --> C1[Completeness]
    C --> C2[Reflexivity]
    C --> C3[Transitivity]
    C --> C4[Convexity]

    D --> D1[Definition]
    D --> D2[Equation]

    E --> E1[Marginal Cost]
    E --> E2[Average Total Cost]
    E --> E3[Optimal Combination of Inputs]

    F --> F1[Production Function]
    F --> F2[Optimal Capital-Labor Ratio]
    F --> F3[Cost Function]
    F --> F4[Average Fixed Cost]
    F --> F5[Marginal Cost]
    F --> F6[Average Variable Cost]

    G --> G1[Definition]
    G --> G2[Equation]
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics and their relationships for the exam on Managerial Economics.
